s.text: This is essentially a make-work scheme: the mailers do the extra work of putting the address on each piece and the Postal Service does the extra work of arranging these pieces in delivery order.

The Postal Service has two basic subclasses for letters and flats: First Class (originally rapid, non-bulk, and sealed against inspection) and Standard A (originally deferrable, bulk, and not sealed against inspection).

If the Postal Service should have a greater degree of pricing freedom and be able to engage in negotiations with selected mailers, one way to provide such freedom, even without further changes, would be to allow the Postal Service to operate under inverse price caps.
